newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Belgrade bourse weekly turnover sharply up.
newsitem.headline: Belgrade bourse weekly turnover sharply up.

text.p: The Belgrade Stock Exchange (BSE) reported on Monday a 67.17 percent jump in its turnover during the week ending November 1, and traders attributed the rise to a big institutional investor appearing on the market.

Total turnover soared to 39.361 million dinars ($7.84 million) from 23.545 million dinars turned over during the previous week. The number of transactions rose to 190 from 156, the bourse said in its report.

Traders ignored Sunday elections and returned to routine with more or less unchanged liquidity. "But one institutional investor comes to the market every month and buys a lot commercial paper," one trader told Reuters without divulging the investor's identity.

"Overall the situation is no better but no worse than it was a week ago. Investors still withdraw money, they close positions and decide to stay away for a while, but companies seem to get around and find other sources of financing," another trader said.
With the reserve requirement up from 10 to 15 percent, the market will face a new wave of tightened liquidity, the trader said.
The bourse traded no central bank short-term bonds over the last week.
Commercial paper segment dominated with 160 transactions worth 27.643 million dinars.
Treasury bills traded 29 times for a volume of 6.559 million dinars.
Interest rate both on commercial paper and treasury bills slightly declined to range between annual 210 and 520 percent.
The bourse reported three deals in wheat selling forward contracts worth 4.8 million dinars. -- Gordana Filipovic, Belgrade newsroom, +381 11 222 4254
